1.text: Combine all-purpose flour, salt, and cream of tartar in a large pot.

2.text: Add 2 cups (470 mL) of water and 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of vegetable oil.

3.text: Heat the ingredients over medium heat while stirring with a wooden spoon.

4.text: Stop stirring and turn off the burner when the clay is a thick ball.

5.text: Place the clay on wax paper so it can cool for 1-2 minutes.

6.text: Knead the room temperature clay until it's soft and smooth.

7.text: Dye your clay using 5-6 drops of food coloring if you like.

8.text: Store your clay in a resealable plastic bag for up to 3 months.

9.text: Allow your clay to air dry if you want to create a sculpture or keepsake.

10.text: Mix 4 c (480 g) of flour and 1.5 c (417 g) of salt in a large bowl.

11.text: Add 1.5  c (350 mL) of water gradually as you stir the mixture.

12.text: Knead the clay until it reaches an even consistency.

13.text: Sculpt the clay as you desire.

14.text: Allow the clay to air dry for 2 days to preserve your model.

15.text: Store unused clay in an airtight container.

16.text: Heat 2⁄3  c (160 mL) of water and 2 c (550 g) of salt for 4 minutes.

17.text: Move the pot to a cool surface and add 1 c (120 g) of cornstarch and .5  c (120 mL) of cold water.

18.text: Knead the mixture until it feels smooth.

19.text: Add a few drops of food coloring if you’d like colored clay.

20.text: Heat the mixture until it starts to feel thick, if necessary.

21.text: Let the clay cool to room temperature before you play with it.

22.text: Allow your clay to air dry for 2 days if you want to preserve it.

23.text: Store your clay in an airtight container when you’re not using it.

24.text: Collect soil that contains clay into a bucket.

25.text: Remove any sticks and debris from the soil.

26.text: Stir enough water into the soil to cover it.

27.text: Let the water settle for 2 minutes so debris will come out.

28.text: Pour the muddy water into a second bucket, but leave the debris in the first.

29.text: Dump the debris and rinse out the bucket.

30.text: Repeat the process until there’s no more debris in your muddy water.

31.text: Leave the bucket of clay-water to dry overnight.

32.text: Pour off the excess water on top of the clay.

33.text: Put the lumpy clay mixture into a piece of fabric to dry for 2 days.

34.text: Leave your clay in the sun until it reaches your desired consistency.
